did.unittitle: James Graham Leyburn Papers

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The materials from Washington & Lee University's Special Collections are made available for use in research, teaching, and private study, pursuant to U.S. Copyright law. The user assumes full responsibility for any use of the materials, including but not limited to, infringement of copyright and publication rights of reproduced materials. prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Preferred citation: [Identification of item], James Graham Leyburn Papers, WLU Coll. 0288, Special Collections and Archives, James G. Leyburn Library, Washington and Lee University, Lexington, VA
In some cases the citation format may vary. Please contact Special Collections' staff to verify the appropriate format.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Series 1 of this collection was given by Dr. Leyburn following his retirement from Washington and Lee University in 1972.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: James Graham Leyburn was born in Hedgesville, West Virginia, on January 17, 1902. He became a professor of sociology and Dean of the University at Washington and Lee in 1947 and held the post of Dean until 1956 continuing as Professor of Sociology until 1972. In the 1920s and 1930s Dr. Leyburn held professional positions at Hollins College, Princeton University, and Yale University. In 1943 he was engaged by the U. S. Government Foreign Economic Administration's Office of the Lend-Lease Administration to participate in a mission in South Africa.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This collection contains many materials relating to the South African mission. Dr. Leyburn saved a number of newspaper articles concerning South Africa which are contained herein. Reports on various industries and other aspects of South Africa are included. Also within this collection are an assortment of Dr. Leyburn's speeches, some of which address South Africa. The remainder of the speeches concern the future of Washington and Lee University.

Among the correspondence in this collection are letters concerning Yale, W&L, and South Africa. There are also letters to his family, including his sister Ellen. A number of reviews of Dr. Leyburn's books, The Haitian People and The Way We Lived, as well as Dr. Leyburn's own reviews of other books are included.

The more telling items of this collection are the numerous student comments that Dr. Leyburn preserved. A voluminous journal of his world travels provides for interesting reading as does the poetry written by John Alexander Graham. Includes one photograph of Leyburn and three other professors (Riegel, Barritt, and Myers).
Appended to this collection are three scrapbooks which provide a record of Dr. Leyburn's activities at W & L and afterward.
There are also Leyburn's musical compositions and diplomas.

did.unittitle: Series 1

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains many materials relating to his South African mission. Dr. Leyburn saved a number of newspaper articles concerning South Africa, which are contained herein. Reports on various industries and other aspects of South Africa are included. Also within this collection is an assortment of Dr. Leyburn's speeches, some of which concern South Africa. The remainder of the speeches concern the future of Washington and Lee University.

Among the correspondence in this collection are letters concerning Yale, Washington and Lee University, and South Africa. There are also letters to his family, including his sister Ellen. A number of reviews of Dr. Leyburn's book, The Haitian People,as well as Dr. Leyburn's own reviews of other books are included.

There are numerous student comments that Dr. Leyburn preserved as well as a voluminous journal of his world travels and the poetry written by John Alexander Graham. Includes one photograph of Leyburn and three other Washington and Lee professors (Riegel, Barritt, and Myers).
Additionally, there are three scrapbooks which provide a record of Dr. Leyburn's activities at Washington and Lee and afterward.

did.unittitle: Control folder

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This folder contains a biography of Dr. James G. Leyburn.

did.unittitle: Leyburn's articles on Africa, "Native Farm Labor," "Disabilities of the Southern African Native," and "The White Man in New Africa."
Articles on education including "The Education of a Southerner" and "A Plan for an Ideal College."
Articles on Haiti and the manuscript that was later extended and became THE HAITIAN PEOPLE.
Entry written by Dr. Leyburn for FUNK AND WAGNALLS STANDARD REFERENCE ENCYCLOPEDIA entitled "Negroes in the U.S."
Numerous articles by Dr. Leyburn on religion
Article: "The Scotch-Irish: An American Social Force," published by NEW SOCIETY in 1962.
Miscellaneous articles on culture including "Notes on American Culture."
Book reviews written by Leyburn between 1961-65 for THE ROANOKE TIMES.
Book reviews written by Leyburn between 1944 and 1972 that appeared in periodicals
Dr. Leyburn's correspondence concerning the abolishment of subsidized athletics which occured at Washington & Lee in 1954.
Clippings from newspapers, the RING-TUM PHI and THE ALUMNI MAGAZINE that deal with the athletic question at W & L.
University rebuttals to the aforementioned clippings and the introduction of "The Leyburn Plan."
Material from Dr. Leyburn's tenure as President of the Gamma Chapter of Virginia from 1962 to 1964.
Information about life at Washington and Lee during the 1960s
Honorary degree candidate correspondence during Dr. Leyburn's time as Dean of the Faculty
Various W & L programs of events including the program of the inauguration of President Fred Cole in 1961.
Various issues of the student newspaper, THE RING-TUM PHI.
Student papers collected by Dr. Leyburn
Correspondence pertaining to Dr. Leyburn's tenure as Editor of SHENANDOAH, the literary magazine published by W & L, in 1959.
Dr. Leyburn's diary
Materials pertaining to Dr. Leyburn's book The Scotch Irish
Correspondence from Terence Hughes concerning the publication of The Scotch Irish
Reviews of The Scotch Irish
Materials dealing with a conference on plantations in Puerto Rico in 1957 and the duPont Conference of 1961
Honors College material
Material on the history of Lexington, Virginia
Miscellaneous papers and the KING JAMES BIBLE
Dr. Leyburn's class lectures for Anthropology 101 and Sociology 303.
Dr. Leyburn's class lectures on the Greek and Latin Classics of Comparative Literature 202.
Dr. Leyburn's class lectures for Greek and Latin Classics, Religion and Society and General Sociology.
Dr. Leyburn's class lectures on General Sociology, class rolls for 1949-1971, and an autographed copy of Ellen Douglas Leyburn's SATIRIC ALLEGORY: MIRROR OF MAN.
Series 2

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series includes correspondence, proofs, and reviews concerning Leyburn's book The Way We Lived. Correspondents include Kenneth Rockwell, Marshall Fishwick, Rupert Nelson Latture, Michael Barr, and Lon K. Savage. There are also photographs of Leyburn, his music programs, and notices of his death.

did.unittitle: Oversized materials
did.physloc: These materials are located in WLU Coll Oversize Drawer 27.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series consists of James G. Leyburn's diplomas and certificates of distinction.
